summary: All living organisms are composed of cells. Unicellular organisms (like bacteria) are made of one cell. Multicellular organisms (like humans) are made of many cells. Topic 2.1 explores the structures and components that make these cells function.

vocab.definition: The fundamental biological unit of all living organisms, consisting of a membrane, DNA, a cytoplasm, and ribosomes
Simple cells which contain a single circular strand of DNA, a cytoplasm, ribosomes, and a membrane, but lack compartmentalized organization
A complex cell characterized by the presence of a membrane-bound nucleus, linear chromosomes, and other membrane-bound organelles
The outer boundary of all cells, separating the cell's interior from its environment, which is semipermeable
The entire content within a cell's outer membrane, excluding the nucleus in eukaryotic cells
The aqueous component of the cytoplasm of a cell
A network of protein filaments and microtubules within a eukaryotic cell that provides structural support, maintains cell shape, and facilitates cell movement and intracellular transport
A rigid or strong outer layer found in plants, fungi, bacteria, algae, and archaea, but not in animal cells, which provides structural support, protection, and shape to the cell
A molecular machine found in all living cells that synthesizes proteins, consisting of a large and small subunit made of rRNA and proteins
Specialized, membrane-bound structures within eukaryotic cells that perform specific functions necessary for the cell's survival
The central part of a eukaryotic cell, containing DNA and controlling cell activities
The membrane surrounding the nucleus within a eukaryotic cell through which mRNA and ribosomes pass
A network of membranes and organelles within eukaryotic cells that modify, package, and transport lipids and proteins
A network of membrane-bound tubules within eukaryotic cells that lacks ribosomes, giving it a smooth appearance which synthesizes lipids and detoxifies drugs
A network of tubules in eukaryotic cells that contains ribosomes and functions in the synthesis and modification of proteins destined for secretion
A cellular organelle in eukaryotic cells that functions as a "post office" for modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids for delivery to their destinations
An organelle in the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells containing degradative enzymes enclosed in a membrane
A space or vesicle within the cytoplasm of a cell, enclosed by a membrane and typically containing fluid
A significant, fluid-filled organelle in plant cells that serves multiple functions, including storage of water, nutrients, and waste products, and structural support
Membrane-bound sacs that move molecules, such as proteins and lipids, between organelles within a eukaryotic cell or to the plasma membrane for secretion
A small, membrane-bound sac within a cell that contains materials, such as hormones, enzymes, or neurotransmitters, to be secreted outside the cell
Organelle responsible for generating most of the chemical energy (ATP) needed to power a cell's biochemical reactions by converting food and oxygen into cellular energy
An organelle in plant and algae cells that carries out photosynthesis, converting light energy into chemical energy in the form of sugars
